98.text: In Troy, there lies the scene.

101.text:
From isles of Greece
The princes orgulous, their high blood chafed,

107.text:
Have to the port of Athens sent their ships,
Fraught with the ministers and instruments

111.text:
Of cruel war: sixty and nine, that wore
Their crownets regal, from the Athenian bay

119.text:
Put forth toward Phrygia; and their vow is
made

122.text:
To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
The ravish'd Helen, Menelaus' queen,

129.text: With wanton Paris sleeps; and that's the quarrel.

133.text:
To Tenedos they come;
And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge

138.text:
Their warlike fraughtage: now on Dardan plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch

145.text:
Their brave pavilions: Priam's six-gated city,
Dardan, and Tymbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,

154.text:
And Antenorides, with massy staples
And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts,

160.text: Sperr up the sons of Troy.

163.text:
Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits,
On one and other side, Trojan and Greek,

170.text:
Sets all on hazard: and hither am I come
A prologue arm'd, but not in confidence

177.text:
Of author's pen or actor's voice, but suited
In like conditions as our argument,

184.text:
To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those

190.text:
broils,
Beginning in the middle, starting thence away

193.text: To what may be digested in a play.

197.text:
Like or find fault; do as your pleasures are:
Now good or bad, 'tis but the chance of war.

212.text:
Enter TROILUS armed, and PANDARUS
TROILUS

216.text:
Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again:
Why should I war without the walls of Troy,

223.text: That find such cruel battle here within?

227.text:
Each Trojan that is master of his heart,
Let him to field; Troilus, alas! hath none.

234.text:
PANDARUS
Will this gear ne'er be mended?

236.text:
TROILUS
The Greeks are strong and skilful to their

239.text:
strength,
Fierce to their skill and to their fierceness

243.text:
valiant;
But I am weaker than a woman's tear,

247.text:
Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance,
Less valiant than the virgin in the night

257.text:
PANDARUS
Well, I have told you enough of this: for

260.text:
my part,
I'll not meddle nor make no further.

263.text:
He that will
have a cake out of the wheat must needs tarry

268.text:
PANDARUS
Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry

273.text:
PANDARUS
Ay, the bolting, but you must tarry the leavening.

278.text:
PANDARUS
Ay, to the leavening; but here's yet in the

281.text:
word
'hereafter' the kneading, the making of the

284.text:
cake, the
heating of the oven and the baking; nay, you

287.text:
must
stay the cooling too, or you may chance to

290.text:
TROILUS
Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be,

295.text: Doth lesser blench at sufferance than I do.

298.text:
At Priam's royal table do I sit;
And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,—

311.text:
PANDARUS
Well, she looked yesternight fairer than ever

313.text:
I saw
her look, or any woman else.

316.text:
TROILUS
I was about to tell thee:—when my heart,

320.text:
As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain,
Lest Hector or my father should perceive me,

329.text:
I have, as when the sun doth light a storm,
Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile:

337.text:
But sorrow, that is couch'd in seeming gladness,
Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

345.text:
PANDARUS
An her hair were not somewhat darker than

348.text:
Helen's—
well, go to—there were no more comparison

351.text:
between
the women: but, for my part, she is my kinswoman;

355.text:
I
would not, as they term it, praise her: but

358.text:
I would
somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as

362.text:
I
will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's

368.text:
I tell thee, Pandarus,—
When I do tell thee, there my hopes lie drown'd,

376.text:
Reply not in how many fathoms deep
They lie indrench'd.

381.text:
I tell thee I am mad
In Cressid's love: thou answer'st 'she is

388.text:
fair;'
Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart

393.text:
Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her
voice,

399.text:
Handlest in thy discourse, O, that her hand,
In whose comparison all whites are ink,

407.text:
Writing their own reproach, to whose soft
seizure

411.text:
The cygnet's down is harsh and spirit of sense
Hard as the palm of ploughman: this thou tell'st

420.text:
me,
As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love

425.text:
her;
But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm,

429.text:
Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given
me

433.text:
PANDARUS
I speak no more than truth.

435.text:
TROILUS
Thou dost not speak so much.

437.text:
PANDARUS
Faith, I'll not meddle in't.

440.text:
Let her be as she is:
if she be fair, 'tis the better for her; an

444.text:
she be
not, she has the mends in her own hands.

447.text:
TROILUS
Good Pandarus, how now, Pandarus!

449.text:
PANDARUS
I have had my labour for my travail; ill-thought

454.text:
on of
her and ill-thought on of you; gone between

457.text:
and
between, but small thanks for my labour.

460.text:
TROILUS
What, art thou angry, Pandarus?

464.text:
PANDARUS
Because she's kin to me, therefore she's not

467.text:
so fair
as Helen: an she were not kin to me, she would

470.text:
be as
fair on Friday as Helen is on Sunday.

475.text:
I care not an she were a black-a-moor; 'tis
all one to me.

479.text:
TROILUS
Say I she is not fair?

481.text:
PANDARUS
I do not care whether you do or no.

484.text:
She's a fool to
stay behind her father; let her to the Greeks;

487.text:
and so
I'll tell her the next time I see her: for

490.text:
my part,
I'll meddle nor make no more i' the matter.

496.text:
PANDARUS
Pray you, speak no more to me: I will leave

499.text:
all as I
found it, and there an end.

503.text:
TROILUS
Peace, you ungracious clamours! peace, rude

515.text:
Helen must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus.

521.text:
I cannot fight upon this argument;
It is too starved a subject for my sword.

527.text:
But Pandarus,—O gods, how do you plague
me!

532.text:
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar;
And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo.

539.text: As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.

542.text:
Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love,
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we?

554.text:
Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl:
Between our Ilium and where she resides,

565.text:
Let it be call'd the wild and wandering flood,
Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar

572.text: Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our bark.

579.text:
AENEAS
How now, Prince Troilus! wherefore not afield?

584.text:
TROILUS
Because not there: this woman's answer sorts,

588.text: For womanish it is to be from thence.

591.text: What news, AEneas, from the field to-day?

593.text:
AENEAS
That Paris is returned home and hurt.

599.text:
TROILUS
Let Paris bleed; 'tis but a scar to scorn;

605.text: Paris is gored with Menelaus' horn.

609.text:
AENEAS
Hark, what good sport is out of town to-day!

612.text:
TROILUS
Better at home, if 'would I might' were 'may.'

615.text: But to the sport abroad: are you bound thither?

620.text:
TROILUS
Come, go we then together.

638.text:
ALEXANDER
Up to the eastern tower,

640.text:
Whose height commands as subject all the vale,
To see the battle.

644.text:
Hector, whose patience
Is, as a virtue, fix'd, to-day was moved:

649.text:
He chid Andromache and struck his armourer,
And, like as there were husbandry in war,

655.text:
Before the sun rose he was harness'd light,
And to the field goes he; where every flower

660.text:
Did, as a prophet, weep what it foresaw
In Hector's wrath.

664.text:
CRESSIDA
What was his cause of anger?

666.text:
ALEXANDER
The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks

670.text:
A lord of Trojan blood, nephew to Hector;
They call him Ajax.

674.text:
CRESSIDA
Good; and what of him?

677.text:
ALEXANDER
They say he is a very man per se,

681.text:
CRESSIDA
So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick,

686.text:
ALEXANDER
This man, lady, hath robbed many beasts of

690.text:
their
particular additions; he is as valiant as

694.text:
the lion,
churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant:

699.text:
a man
into whom nature hath so crowded humours that

702.text:
his
valour is crushed into folly, his folly sauced

706.text:
with
discretion: there is no man hath a virtue

709.text:
that he
hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint

713.text:
but he
carries some stain of it: he is melancholy

716.text:
without
cause, and merry against the hair: he hath

721.text:
the
joints of every thing, but everything so out

724.text:
of joint
that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and

728.text:
no use,
or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

732.text:
CRESSIDA
But how should this man, that makes

737.text:
ALEXANDER
They say he yesterday coped Hector in the

739.text:
battle and
struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof

744.text:
hath
ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

754.text:
ALEXANDER
As may be in the world, lady.

760.text:
PANDARUS
Good morrow, cousin Cressid: what do you talk

770.text:
PANDARUS
What were you talking of when I came?

772.text:
Was Hector
armed and gone ere ye came to Ilium?

774.text:
Helen was not
up, was she?

776.text:
CRESSIDA
Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

780.text:
PANDARUS
Even so: Hector was stirring early.

782.text:
CRESSIDA
That were we talking of, and of his anger.

788.text:
PANDARUS
True, he was so: I know the cause too: he'll

792.text:
lay
about him to-day, I can tell them that: and

795.text:
there's
Troilus will not come far behind him: let

798.text:
them take
heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

800.text:
CRESSIDA
What, is he angry too?

804.text: Troilus is the better man of the two.

806.text:
CRESSIDA
O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

809.text:
PANDARUS
What, not between Troilus and Hector?

811.text:
Do you know a
man if you see him?

813.text:
CRESSIDA
Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

816.text:
PANDARUS
Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

819.text:
CRESSIDA
Then you say as I say; for, I am sure, he

823.text:
PANDARUS
No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

826.text:
CRESSIDA
'Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

835.text:
PANDARUS
Condition, I had gone barefoot to India.

840.text:
PANDARUS
Himself! no, he's not himself: would a' were

844.text:
Well, the gods are above; time must friend
or end: well, Troilus, well: I would my heart

851.text: No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

858.text:
PANDARUS
Th' other's not come to't; you shall tell

861.text:
me another
tale, when th' other's come to't.

863.text:
Hector shall not
have his wit this year.

865.text:
CRESSIDA
He shall not need it, if he have his own.

872.text:
CRESSIDA
'Twould not become him; his own's better.

875.text:
PANDARUS
You have no judgment, niece: Helen

877.text:
herself swore th' other day, that Troilus,
for

880.text:
a brown favour—for so 'tis, I must confess,—
not brown neither,—

886.text:
PANDARUS
'Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

889.text:
CRESSIDA
To say the truth, true and not true.

892.text:
PANDARUS
She praised his complexion above Paris.

895.text:
CRESSIDA
Why, Paris hath colour enough.

898.text:
CRESSIDA
Then Troilus should have too much: if she

901.text:
praised
him above, his complexion is higher than his;

906.text:
he
having colour enough, and the other higher,

908.text:
is too
flaming a praise for a good complexion.

912.text:
I had as
lief Helen's golden tongue had commended Troilus

918.text: I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

920.text:
CRESSIDA
Then she's a merry Greek indeed.

923.text:
PANDARUS
Nay, I am sure she does.

925.text:
She came to him th' other
day into the compassed window,—and, you

929.text:
know, he
has not past three or four hairs on his chin,—

CRESSIDA

935.text:
his

PANDARUS
Why, he is very young: and yet will he, within

940.text: three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

942.text:
CRESSIDA

PANDARUS
But to prove to you that Helen loves him:

948.text:
she came
and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin—

CRESSIDA

954.text:
PANDARUS
Why, you know 'tis dimpled: I think his smiling

957.text: becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

CRESSIDA
O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn.

PANDARUS

I cannot choose but laugh, to think how she

tickled

PANDARUS
And she takes upon her to spy a white hair

PANDARUS

and Helen so blushed, an Paris so chafed,

CRESSIDA
So let it now; for it has been while going

an 'twere

But the protractive trials of great Jove
To find persistive constancy in men:

1522.text:
The fineness of which metal is not found
In fortune's love; for then the bold and coward,

1529.text:
The wise and fool, the artist and unread,
The hard and soft seem all affined and kin:

1536.text:
But, in the wind and tempest of her frown,
Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan,

1543.text:
Puffing at all, winnows the light away;
And what hath mass or matter, by itself

1549.text: Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

1552.text:
NESTOR
With due observance of thy godlike seat,

1556.text:
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words.

1561.text:
In the reproof of chance
Lies the true proof of men: the sea being

1566.text:
smooth,
How many shallow bauble boats dare sail

1570.text:
Upon her patient breast, making their way
With those of nobler bulk!

1575.text:
But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold

1581.text:
The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains
cut,

1585.text:
Bounding between the two moist elements,
Like Perseus' horse: where's then the saucy

1590.text:
boat
Whose weak untimber'd sides but even now

1596.text:
Either to harbour fled,
Or made a toast for Neptune.

1601.text:
Even so
Doth valour's show and valour's worth divide

1605.text:
In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness
The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze

1612.text:
Than by the tiger; but when the splitting
wind

1616.text:
Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks,
And flies fled under shade, why, then the

1622.text:
thing of courage
As roused with rage with rage doth sympathize,

1628.text:
And with an accent tuned in selfsame key
Retorts to chiding fortune.

1634.text:
Thou great commander, nerve and bone of Greece,
Heart of our numbers, soul and only spirit.

1641.text:
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut up, hear what Ulysses speaks.

1647.text:
Besides the applause and approbation To which,
To AGAMEMNON

1652.text:
most mighty for thy place and sway,
To NESTOR

1655.text:
And thou most reverend for thy stretch'd-out
life

1658.text:
I give to both your speeches, which were such
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece

1663.text:
Should hold up high in brass, and such again
As venerable Nestor, hatch'd in silver,

1670.text:
Should with a bond of air, strong as the axle-tree
On which heaven rides, knit all the Greekish

1677.text:
ears
To his experienced tongue, yet let it please

1681.text:
both,
Thou great, and wise, to hear Ulysses speak.

1686.text:
AGAMEMNON
Speak, prince of Ithaca; and be't of less

1690.text:
expect
That matter needless, of importless burden,

1694.text:
Divide thy lips, than we are confident,
When rank Thersites opes his mastic jaws,

1700.text: We shall hear music, wit and oracle.

1703.text:
ULYSSES
Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down,

1707.text:
And the great Hector's sword had lack'd a
master,

1713.text:
The specialty of rule hath been neglected:
And, look, how many Grecian tents do stand

1720.text: Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions.

1725.text:
When that the general is not like the hive
To whom the foragers shall all repair,

1733.text:
Degree being vizarded,
The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask.

1739.text:
The heavens themselves, the planets and this
centre

1742.text:
Observe degree, priority and place,
Insisture, course, proportion, season, form,

1750.text:
Office and custom, in all line of order;
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol

1757.text:
In noble eminence enthroned and sphered
Amidst the other; whose medicinable eye

1763.text:
Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil,
And posts, like the commandment of a king,

1770.text:
Sans cheque to good and bad: but when the
planets

1775.text:
In evil mixture to disorder wander,
What plagues and what portents! what mutiny!

1781.text: What raging of the sea! shaking of earth!

1784.text:
Commotion in the winds! frights, changes,
horrors,

1787.text:
Divert and crack, rend and deracinate
The unity and married calm of states

1796.text:
O, when degree is shaked,
Which is the ladder to all high designs,

1805.text:
How could communities,
Degrees in schools and brotherhoods in cities,

1810.text:
Peaceful commerce from dividable shores,
The primogenitive and due of birth,

1816.text:
Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels,
But by degree, stand in authentic place?

1825.text:
Take but degree away, untune that string,
And, hark, what discord follows! each thing

1833.text:
meets
In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters

1837.text:
Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores
And make a sop of all this solid globe:

1843.text:
Strength should be lord of imbecility,
And the rude son should strike his father

1849.text:
dead:
Force should be right; or rather, right and

1853.text:
wrong,
Between whose endless jar justice resides,

1857.text:
Should lose their names, and so should justice
too.

1861.text:
Then every thing includes itself in power,
Power into will, will into appetite;

1868.text:
And appetite, an universal wolf,
So doubly seconded with will and power,

1875.text:
Must make perforce an universal prey,
And last eat up himself.

1880.text:
Great Agamemnon,
This chaos, when degree is suffocate,

1888.text:
And this neglection of degree it is
That by a pace goes backward, with a purpose

1896.text:
The general's disdain'd
By him one step below, he by the next,

1901.text:
That next by him beneath; so every step,
Exampled by the first pace that is sick

1907.text:
Of his superior, grows to an envious fever
Of pale and bloodless emulation:

1914.text:
And 'tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot,
Not her own sinews.

1921.text:
To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.

1928.text:
NESTOR
Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd

1931.text: The fever whereof all our power is sick.

1934.text:
AGAMEMNON
The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses,

1938.text:
ULYSSES
The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns

1941.text:
The sinew and the forehand of our host,
Having his ear full of his airy fame,

1948.text:
Grows dainty of his worth, and in his tent
Lies mocking our designs: with him Patroclus

1956.text:
Upon a lazy bed the livelong day
Breaks scurril jests;

1961.text:
And with ridiculous and awkward action,
Which, slanderer, he imitation calls,

1970.text:
Sometime, great Agamemnon,
Thy topless deputation he puts on,

1976.text:
And, like a strutting player, whose conceit
Lies in his hamstring, and doth think it rich

1981.text:
To hear the wooden dialogue and sound
'Twixt his stretch'd footing and the scaffoldage,—

1987.text:
Such to-be-pitied and o'er-wrested seeming
He acts thy greatness in: and when he speaks,

1994.text:
'Tis like a chime a-mending; with terms unsquared,
Which, from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropp'd

2004.text:
At this fusty stuff
The large Achilles, on his press'd bed lolling,

2009.text:
From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause;
Cries 'Excellent! 'tis Agamemnon just.

2016.text:
Now play me Nestor; hem, and stroke thy beard,
As he being drest to some oration.'

2023.text:
That's done, as near as the extremest ends
Of parallels, as like as Vulcan and his wife:

2036.text:
Now play him me, Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night alarm.'

2041.text:
And then, forsooth, the faint defects of age
Must be the scene of mirth; to cough and spit,

2047.text:
And, with a palsy-fumbling on his gorget,
Shake in and out the rivet: and at this sport

2054.text:
Sir Valour dies; cries 'O, enough, Patroclus;
Or give me ribs of steel!

2061.text:
I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleen.'

2065.text:
And in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes,

2072.text:
Severals and generals of grace exact,
Achievements, plots, orders, preventions,

2078.text:
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Success or loss, what is or is not, serves

2084.text: As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

2089.text:
NESTOR
And in the imitation of these twain—

2092.text:
Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns
With an imperial voice—many are infect.

2100.text:
Ajax is grown self-will'd, and bears his head
In such a rein, in full as proud a place

2106.text:
As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him;
Makes factious feasts; rails on our state

2112.text:
of war,
Bold as an oracle, and sets Thersites,

2116.text:
A slave whose gall coins slanders like a mint,
To match us in comparisons with dirt,

2124.text:
To weaken and discredit our exposure,
How rank soever rounded in with danger.

2130.text:
ULYSSES
They tax our policy, and call it cowardice,

2134.text:
Count wisdom as no member of the war,
Forestall prescience, and esteem no act

2141.text:
But that of hand: the still and mental parts,
That do contrive how many hands shall strike,

2149.text:
When fitness calls them on, and know by measure
Of their observant toil the enemies' weight,—

2155.text:
Why, this hath not a finger's dignity:
They call this bed-work, mappery, closet-war;

2164.text:
So that the ram that batters down the wall,
For the great swing and rudeness of his poise,

2170.text:
They place before his hand that made the engine,
Or those that with the fineness of their souls

2180.text:
NESTOR
Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse

2194.text:
AGAMEMNON
What would you 'fore our tent?

2197.text:
AENEAS
Is this great Agamemnon's tent, I pray you?

2201.text:
AENEAS
May one, that is a herald and a prince,

2204.text: Do a fair message to his kingly ears?

2206.text:
AGAMEMNON
With surety stronger than Achilles' arm

2209.text:
'Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one
voice

2215.text:
AENEAS
Fair leave and large security.

2217.text:
How may
A stranger to those most imperial looks

2220.text: Know them from eyes of other mortals?

2224.text:
I ask, that I might waken reverence,
And bid the cheek be ready with a blush

2228.text:
Modest as morning when she coldly eyes
The youthful Phoebus:

2232.text: Which is that god in office, guiding men?

2235.text: Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

2236.text:
AGAMEMNON
This Trojan scorns us; or the men of Troy

2242.text:
AENEAS
Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd,

2246.text:
As bending angels; that's their fame in peace:
But when they would seem soldiers, they have

2251.text:
galls,
Good arms, strong joints, true swords; and,

2255.text:
Jove's accord,
Nothing so full of heart.

2257.text:
But peace, AEneas,
Peace, Trojan; lay thy finger on thy lips!

2260.text:
The worthiness of praise distains his worth,
If that the praised himself bring the praise

2265.text:
forth:
But what the repining enemy commends,

2269.text:
That breath fame blows; that praise, sole
sure,

2274.text:
AGAMEMNON
Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself AEneas?

2278.text:
AENEAS
Ay, Greek, that is my name.

2280.text:
AGAMEMNON
What's your affair I pray you?

2282.text:
AENEAS
Sir, pardon; 'tis for Agamemnon's ears.

2285.text:
AGAMEMNON
He hears naught privately that comes from

2289.text:
AENEAS
Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him:

2291.text:
I bring a trumpet to awake his ear,
To set his sense on the attentive bent,

2297.text:
AGAMEMNON
Speak frankly as the wind;

2300.text:
It is not Agamemnon's sleeping hour:
That thou shalt know.

2305.text:
Trojan, he is awake,
He tells thee so himself.

2311.text:
Send thy brass voice through all these lazy
tents;

2313.text:
And every Greek of mettle, let him know,
What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud.

2319.text:
We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy
A prince call'd Hector,—Priam is his father,—

2324.text:
Who in this dull and long-continued truce
Is rusty grown: he bade me take a trumpet,

2335.text:
If there be one among the fair'st of Greece
That holds his honour higher than his ease,

2339.text:
That seeks his praise more than he fears his
peril,

2343.text:
That knows his valour, and knows not his fear,
That loves his mistress more than in confession,

2349.text:
With truant vows to her own lips he loves,
And dare avow her beauty and her worth

2354.text: In other arms than hers,—to him this challenge.

2358.text:
Hector, in view of Trojans and of Greeks,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it,

2365.text:
He hath a lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greek did compass in his arms,

2370.text:
And will to-morrow with his trumpet call
Midway between your tents and walls of Troy,

2374.text:
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love:
If any come, Hector shall honour him;

2381.text:
If none, he'll say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian dames are sunburnt and not worth

2389.text:
AGAMEMNON
This shall be told our lovers, Lord AEneas;

2393.text:
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home: but we are soldiers;

2400.text:
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love!

2407.text:
If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, I am

2415.text:
NESTOR
Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man

2417.text:
When Hector's grandsire suck'd: he is old
now;

2421.text:
But if there be not in our Grecian host
One noble man that hath one spark of fire,

2428.text:
To answer for his love, tell him from me
I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver

2435.text:
And in my vantbrace put this wither'd brawn,
And meeting him will tell him that my lady

2441.text:
Was fairer than his grandam and as chaste
As may be in the world: his youth in flood,

2447.text:
I'll prove this truth with my three drops
of blood.

2451.text:
AENEAS
Now heavens forbid such scarcity of youth!

2455.text:
AGAMEMNON
Fair Lord AEneas, let me touch your hand;

2458.text: To our pavilion shall I lead you, sir.

2461.text:
Achilles shall have word of this intent;
So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to

2467.text:
tent:
Yourself shall feast with us before you go

2471.text: And find the welcome of a noble foe.

2474.text: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR

2479.text:
ULYSSES
I have a young conception in my brain;

2483.text: Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

2489.text:
Blunt wedges rive hard knots: the seeded pride
That hath to this maturity blown up

2494.text:
In rank Achilles must or now be cropp'd,
Or, shedding, breed a nursery of like evil,

2504.text:
ULYSSES
This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,

2508.text:
However it is spread in general name,
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

2513.text:
NESTOR
The purpose is perspicuous even as substance,

2517.text:
Whose grossness little characters sum up:
And, in the publication, make no strain,

2523.text:
But that Achilles, were his brain as barren
As banks of Libya,—though, Apollo knows,

2529.text:
'Tis dry enough,—will, with great speed
of judgment,

2533.text:
Ay, with celerity, find Hector's purpose
Pointing on him.

2538.text:
ULYSSES
And wake him to the answer, think you?

2541.text:
NESTOR
Yes, 'tis most meet: whom may you else oppose,

2545.text:
That can from Hector bring his honour off,
If not Achilles?

2548.text:
Though't be a sportful combat,
Yet in the trial much opinion dwells;

2553.text:
For here the Trojans taste our dear'st repute
With their finest palate: and trust to me,

2561.text:
Ulysses,
Our imputation shall be oddly poised

2564.text:
In this wild action; for the success,
Although particular, shall give a scantling

2569.text:
Of good or bad unto the general;
And in such indexes, although small pricks

2575.text:
To their subsequent volumes, there is seen
The baby figure of the giant mass

2580.text: Of things to come at large.

2583.text:
It is supposed
He that meets Hector issues from our choice

2587.text:
And choice, being mutual act of all our souls,
Makes merit her election, and doth boil,

2594.text:
As 'twere from us all, a man distill'd
Out of our virtues; who miscarrying,

2600.text:
What heart receives from hence the conquering
part,

2603.text: To steel a strong opinion to themselves?

2607.text:
Which entertain'd, limbs are his instruments,
In no less working than are swords and bows

2614.text:
ULYSSES
Give pardon to my speech:

2617.text: Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector.

2622.text:
Let us, like merchants, show our foulest wares,
And think, perchance, they'll sell; if not,

2629.text:
The lustre of the better yet to show,
Shall show the better.

2634.text:
Do not consent
That ever Hector and Achilles meet;

2638.text:
For both our honour and our shame in this
Are dogg'd with two strange followers.

2644.text:
NESTOR
I see them not with my old eyes: what are

2650.text:
ULYSSES
What glory our Achilles shares from Hector,

2653.text:
Were he not proud, we all should share with
him:

2656.text:
But he already is too insolent;
A nd we were better parch in Afric sun

2662.text:
Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes,
Should he 'scape Hector fair: if he were foil'd,

2669.text:
Why then, we did our main opinion crush
In taint of our best man.

2675.text:
No, make a lottery;
And, by device, let blockish Ajax draw

2681.text:
The sort to fight with Hector: among ourselves
Give him allowance for the better man;

2689.text:
For that will physic the great Myrmidon
Who broils in loud applause, and make him

2695.text:
fall
His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends.

2700.text:
If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off,
We'll dress him up in voices: if he fail,

2707.text:
Yet go we under our opinion still
That we have better men.

2712.text:
But, hit or miss,
Our project's life this shape of sense assumes:

2718.text: Ajax employ'd plucks down Achilles' plumes.

2724.text:
Now I begin to relish thy advice;
And I will give a taste of it forthwith

2729.text: To Agamemnon: go we to him straight.
